revision.text:
{{dynamic list}} This is a list of '''[[Jew]]ish [[anarchists]]'''.
{{compact ToC|center=yes|nobreak=yes|seealso=yes|notesfirst=yes|refs=yes|further=yes}}
{| |valign="top" width=33%|
==A== *[[Jacob Abrams]]<ref name=Christenson>{{cite book |last1=Christenson |first1=Ron, ed. |title=Political Trials in History: From Antiquity to the Present |year=1991 |publisher=Transaction Publishers |location=New Brunswick, N.J. |isbn=0-88738-406-4 |page=1 }}</ref> *[[Paul Avrich]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.deadanarchists.org/contemporaries/Avrich.html |title=Love and Anarchy: A Profile and Interview with Paul Avrich |accessdate=December 4, 2017 |last=Phillips |first=Susan |year=2002 |publisher=Dead Anarchists |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513171911/http://www.deadanarchists.org/contemporaries/Avrich.html |archivedate=May 13, 2008 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,1750715,00.html |title=Paul Avrich |accessdate=January 25, 2008 |last=Christie |first=Stuart |authorlink=Stuart Christie |date=April 10, 2006 |work=[[The Guardian]] }}</ref>
==B== *[[Aaron Baron]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://libcom.org/history/baron-aron-davidovich-aka-kantorovich-faktorovich-poleyevoy-1891-1937 |title=Baron, Aron Davidovich (aka Kantorovich, Faktorovich, Poleyevoy) 1891-1937 |accessdate=June 10, 2012 |publisher=Libcom.org }}</ref> *[[Fanya Baron]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.j-grit.com/radicals-fanya-baron-anarchist-revolutionary.php |title=Fanya Baron - Jewish Anarchist/Revolutionary |accessdate=May 8, 2009 |publisher=J-Grit }}</ref> *[[Julian Beck]]<ref>Beeber, p. 43.</ref> *[[Alexander Berkman]]<ref>Avrich, ''Anarchist Portraits'', p. 201.</ref> *[[David Bernstein (anarchist)|David Bernstein]]<ref name=Moya-28/> *[[Walter Block]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/block/block21.html |title=On Autobiography |accessdate=September 24, 2008 |last=Block |first=Walter |authorlink=Walter Block |date=December 4, 2002 |publisher=[[LewRockwell.com]] }}</ref> *[[Abe Bluestein]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.lib.umich.edu/labadie-collection/archives-and-manuscripts-f |title=Archives and Manuscripts A–F |accessdate=December 4, 2017 |last=Herrada |first=Julie A. |date=November 14, 2017 |publisher=[[Labadie Collection]], [[University of Michigan Library]] }}</ref> *[[Mykel Board]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Board |first=Mykel |title=I A, Me-ist or The Portable Mykel Board |year=2005 |publisher=Hope and Nonthings |location=Chicago |isbn=0-9707458-9-3 |pages=9, 11 }}</ref> *[[Dmitry Bogrov]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Dubnow |first=Simon |authorlink=Simon Dubnow |title=History of the Jews in Russia and Poland, Volume III |year=1920 |publisher=Jewish Publication Society of America |location=Philadelphia |oclc=32545697 |pages=164–165 }}</ref> *[[Murray Bookchin]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dwardmac.pitzer.edu/Anarchist_Archives/bookchin/bio1.html |title=A Short Biography of Murray Bookchin |accessdate=December 24, 2007 |last=Biehl |first=Janet |authorlink=Janet Biehl |publisher=[[Anarchy Archives]] }}</ref> *[[Martin Buber]]<ref>Löwy, pp. 54-56.</ref>
==C== *[[Noam Chomsky]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://globetrotter.berkeley.edu/people2/Chomsky/chomsky-con0.html |title=Activism, Anarchism, and Power: Conversation with Noam Chomsky |accessdate=December 24, 2007 |last=Kreisler |first=Harry |date=March 22, 2002 |work=Conversations with History |publisher=Institute of International Studies, University of California, Berkeley }}</ref> *[[Selig Silberstein]] (Selig Cohen)<ref>{{cite book |last1=Falk |first1=Candace, ed. |title=Making Speech Free, 1902–1909 |series=Emma Goldman: A Documentary History of the American Years |volume=2 |year=2005 |publisher=University of California Press |location=Berkeley |isbn=0-520-22569-4 |page=297 }}</ref> *[[Daniel Cohn-Bendit]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wadlow |first=Rene |date=Fall 1999 |title=French Greens Surge Ahead in Elections for European Parliament |journal=Synthesis/Regeneration |volume=20 |publisher=Gateway Green Alliance |location=St. Louis, Mo. |url=http://www.greens.org/s-r/20/20-06.html |accessdate=May 5, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bu.edu/today/2008/%E2%80%9Cdany-the-red%E2%80%9D-on-student-revolutions-then-and-now/ |title="Dany the Red" on Student Revolutions, Then and Now |accessdate=December 4, 2017 |last=Daniloff |first=Caleb |date=March 18, 2008 |work=BU Today |publisher=[[Boston University]] }}</ref>
==D== *[[Sam Dolgoff]]<ref>Avrich, ''Anarchist Voices'', p. 419.</ref> *[[Eric Drooker]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.drooker.com/bio/essay_victoria_h.html |title=Skeletons and Silhouettes: Optimism in Eric Drooker's Art |accessdate=December 4, 2017 |last=Huang |first=Victoria |date=March 17, 2004 |publisher=[[Eric Drooker]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505092137/http://www.drooker.com/bio/essay_victoria_h.html |archivedate=May 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2005/03/27/BAGDLBVFHO1.DTL |title=Authority a four-letter word at this book fair |accessdate=May 16, 2008 |last=Marech |first=Rona |date=March 27, 2005 |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] }}</ref>
==E== *[[David Edelstadt]]<ref>Avrich, ''Anarchist Portraits'', p. 177.</ref> *[[Carl Einstein]]<ref>{{cite journal |title=Revolutionary Portraits: Carl Einstein |journal=Organise! |volume=57 |page=28 |publisher=Anarchist Federation |location=London |url=http://flag.blackened.net/af/org/org57.pdf |accessdate=May 5, 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080511182955/http://flag.blackened.net/af/org/org57.pdf |archive-date=2008-05-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Mascelli |first=Marzia |editor=[[Carl Einstein]] |title=Bebuquin, or the miracle amateurs |accessdate=May 5, 2008 |year=2006 |origyear=1912 |publisher=Le nubi edizioni |location=Rome |chapter=Introduction |chapterurl=http://www.sguardi.info/index.php?id=234,801,0,0,1,0 }}</ref>

Friedman }}</ref> *[[Abraham Frumkin]]<ref name=Avrich-197>Avrich, ''Anarchist Portraits'', p. 197.</ref> | valign="top" width=15 | | valign="top" width=33% |
==G== *[[Allen Ginsberg]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Ginsberg |first=Allen |title=Journals: Early Fifties, Early Sixties |year=1977 |publisher=Grove Press |location=New York |isbn=0-8021-3347-9 |page=17 }}</ref> *[[Emma Goldman]]<ref>Avrich, ''Anarchist Portraits'', p. 176.</ref> *[[Marie Goldsmith]]<ref>{{cite book |last1=Woodcock |first1=George |authorlink1=George Woodcock |last2=Avakumović |first2=Ivan |title=[[The Anarchist Prince]] |year=1950 |location=London |publisher=[[Boardman Books|Boardman]] |page=360 }}</ref> *[[Paul Goodman (writer)|Paul Goodman]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Stoehr |first=Taylor, ed. |title=Decentralizing Power: Paul Goodman's Social Criticism |year=1994 |publisher=Black Rose Books |location=Montréal |isbn=1-55164-008-2 |pages=viii, 189 }}</ref> *[[Abba Gordin]]<ref>Avrich, ''Russian Anarchists'', pp. 237, 249, 253.</ref> *[[V. L. Gordin]]<ref>Avrich, ''Russian Anarchists'', pp. 237, 253.</ref> *[[Uri Gordon]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/a-conversation-with-uri-gordon-1.258123 |title=A conversation with Uri Gordon |last=Green |first=David B. |date=November 24, 2008 |work=Haaretz |accessdate=March 15, 2013 }}</ref> *[[Philip Grosser]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Brock |first=Peter, ed. |title=These Strange Criminals: An Anthology of Prison Memoirs by Conscientious Objectors from the Great War to the Cold War |year=1980 |publisher=University of Toronto Press |location=Toronto |isbn=0-8020-8707-8 |page=157 }}</ref> *[[Iuda Grossman]] (Grossman-Roshchin)<ref>{{cite book |last=Munitz |first=Benzion |editor-last=Miller |editor-first=Jack |title=Jews in Soviet Culture |year=1984 |publisher=Transaction Books |location=Rutgers, N.J. |isbn=0-87855-495-5 |page=147 |chapter=A Structural Study of Jews in Russian Literary Criticism, 1917–32 }}</ref> *[[Mark Gunnery]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.riotfolk.org/?m=markgunnery |title=Mark Gunnery |publisher=Riotfolk |accessdate=January 14, 2010 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.soundclick.com/bands/default.cfm?bandID=270479 |title=Riot-Folk |publisher=[[SoundClick]] |accessdate=January 14, 2010 }}</ref>
==H== *[[Abraham Hartenstein]]<ref>Moya, p. 29.</ref> *[[Paul Hefeld]]<ref name=AJYB>{{cite journal |last=Friedenberg |first=Albert M. |year=1909 |title=The Year 5669 |journal=[[American Jewish Year Book]] |volume=11 |page=73 |publisher=[[American Jewish Committee]] |location=Philadelphia |url=http://www.ajcarchives.org/AJC_DATA/Files/1909_1910_4_YearReview.pdf |accessdate=May 5, 2008 }}</ref><ref name=Yard>{{cite web |url=http://www.historybytheyard.co.uk/Tottenham_Outrage.htm |title=The Tottenham Outrage |accessdate=May 5, 2008 |last=Fido |first=Martin |authorlink=Martin Fido |author2=Keith Skinner |publisher=History by the Yard }}</ref> *[[Julio Herschenbaum]]<ref name=Moya-28>Moya, p. 28.</ref> *[[Hirsh Hershman]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Margolis |first=Rebecca E. |year=2001 |title=A Tempest in Three Teapots: Yom Kippur Balls in London, New York and Montreal |journal=Canadian Jewish Studies |volume=9 |page=55 |publisher=Association for Canadian Jewish Studies |location=Montreal |url=https://pi.library.yorku.ca/ojs/index.php/cjs/article/viewFile/19927/18631 |accessdate=May 27, 2009 }}</ref> *[[Abbie Hoffman]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Hoffman |first=Abbie |authorlink=Abbie Hoffman |title=Soon to Be a Major Motion Picture |year=1980 |publisher=Perigee Books |location=New York |isbn=0-399-50503-2 |pages=2, 128 }}</ref> *[[Johannes Holzmann]] (Senna Hoy)<ref>{{cite book |first=Walter |last=Fähnders |chapter=Anarchism and Homosexuality in Wilhelmine Germany: Senna Hoy, Erich Mühsam, John Henry Mackay |editor1-first=Gert |editor1-last=Hekma |editor2-first=Harry |editor2-last=Oosterhuis |editor3-first=James |editor3-last=Steakley |title=Gay Men and the Sexual History of the Political Left |year=1995 |publisher=The Haworth Press |location=Binghamton, N.Y. |isbn=978-1-56024-724-1 |page=125 }}</ref>
==K== *[[Franz Kafka]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Löwy |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Löwy |date=Summer 1997 |title=Franz Kafka and Libertarian Socialism |journal=[[New Politics (magazine)|New Politics]] |volume=6 |issue=3 |url=http://nova.wpunj.edu/newpolitics/issue23/lowy23.htm |accessdate=December 4, 2017 }}</ref> *[[Tuli Kupferberg]]<ref>Beeber, p. 5.</ref>

==M== *[[Albert Meltzer]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/obituary-albert-meltzer-1346506.html |title=Obituary: Albert Meltzer |accessdate=December 24, 2007 |last=Walter |first=Nicolas |authorlink=Nicolas Walter |date=May 10, 1996 |work=[[The Independent]] }}</ref> *[[Ida Mett]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Skirda |first=Alexandre |title=Nestor Makhno: Anarchy's Cossack |year=2004 |publisher=AK Press |location=Oakland |isbn=1-902593-68-5 |page=340 }}</ref> *[[Mark Mratchny]]<ref name=Avrich-197/> *[[Erich Mühsam]]<ref>{{cite book |last=Mühsam |first=Erich |authorlink=Erich Mühsam |title=Thunderation!: Folk Play with Song and Dance |origyear=1930 |year=2001 |publisher=Associated University Presses |location=Cranbury, N.J. |isbn=0-8387-5416-3 |page=12 }}</ref>

Sandy, ed. |title=Jews in American Politics |year=2001 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |location=Lanham, Md. |isbn=0-7425-0181-7 |page=197 }}</ref> *[[David Rovics]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://zcomm.org/znetarticle/the-soundtrack-to-protest-by-site-administrator/ |title=The Soundtrack to Protest |accessdate=December 4, 2017 |last=Dineen |first=Matt |author2=David Rovics |date=September 24, 2006 |publisher=[[Z Communications|ZNet]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ainfos.ca/07/may/ainfos00256.html |title=David Rovics - The Anarchist Troubadour - Songs of Social Significance |accessdate=June 21, 2008 |last= |first= |date=May 16, 2007 |publisher=A - Infos Information Center }}</ref>

page.title: List of drugs banned by WADA

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/59.167.215.35|59.167.215.35]] ([[User talk:59.167.215.35|talk]]) to last version by ClueBot NG
revision.text:
{{Doping in sport sidebar |expanded=Doping related lists}} This '''list of [[drug]]s banned by [[World Anti-Doping Agency|WADA]]'''<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.wada-ama.org/sites/default/files/resources/files/2016-09-29_-_wada_prohibited_list_2017_eng_final.pdf | title = World Anti-Doping Code: International Standard Prohibited List | date = January 2017 | publisher = [[World Anti-Doping Agency]] | accessdate=2017-02-23}}</ref> is determined by the [[World Anti-Doping Agency]], established in 1999 to deal with the increasing problem of [[Use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport|doping in the sports world]]. The banned substances and techniques fall into the following categories: [[androgen]]s, [[blood doping]], [[peptide hormone]]s, [[stimulant]]s, [[diuretic]]s, [[narcotic]]s, and [[cannabinoid]]s.
==Blood doping== [[Blood doping]] is the injection of [[red blood cell]]s, related blood products that contain red blood cells, or artificial [[oxygen]] containers. This is done by extracting and storing one's own blood prior to an athletic competition, well in advance of the competition so that the body can replenish its natural levels of red blood cells, and subsequently injecting the stored blood immediately before competition. The resulting unnatural level of red blood cells improves oxygen transport and athletic endurance; thus, it is prohibited in most events. It is often used in [[extreme sports]] like [[cycling]], [[snowboarding]], and [[skiing]] where endurance is highly valued. The most famous example of this type of doping is [[Lance Armstrong]]'s performance in the [[Tour de France]].<ref>https://nypost.com/2017/06/30/lance-armstrong-ruined-his-life-with-a-ped-that-might-be-useless/</ref>
== Banned androgenic agents == Banned androgenic agents are either [[anabolic steroid]]s, which increase [[testosterone]] and [[epitestosterone]], thereby improving muscle strength and endurance, or beta-2 agonists (see [[adrenergic beta-agonist]]). Andro, DHEA, [[stanozolol]], [[testosterone (medication)|testosterone]], and [[nandrolone]], or derivates (see below) are banned anabolic steroids. Beta-2 agonists can act as [[bronchodilator]]s and increase [[heart rate]]s, in addition to their mild androgenic effects. Other banned androgenic agents include [[bambuterol]], [[clenbuterol]], [[salbutamol]], [[tibolone]], [[zeranol]], [[zilpaterol]], and selective androgen receptor modulators. While a few of the banned drugs are endogenous, that is they are normally produced in the human body, most of the banned drug are exogenous drugs chemically produced.
===Exogenous anabolic androgenic steroids=== This is the complete list of exogenous (non-natural) androgenic agents banned as of January 1, 2012: {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[1-Androstenediol]] * [[1-Androstenedione]] * [[Bolandiol]] * [[Bolasterone]] * [[Boldenone]] * [[Boldione]] * [[Calusterone]] * [[Clostebol]] * [[Danazol]] * [[Dehydrochlormethyltestosterone]] * [[Desoxymethyltestosterone]] * [[Drostanolone]] * [[Ethylestrenol]] * [[Fluoxymesterone]] * [[Formebolone]] * [[Furazabol]] * [[Gestrinone]] * [[4-Hydroxytestosterone]] * [[Mestanolone]] * [[Mesterolone]] * [[Metenolone]] * [[Methandienone]] * [[Methandriol]] {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Methasterone]] * [[Methyldienolone]] * [[Methyl-1-testosterone]] * [[Methylnortestosterone]] * [[Methyltestosterone]] * [[Metribolone]] * [[Mibolerone]] * [[Nandrolone]] * [[Bolandione|19-Norandrostenedione]] * [[Norboletone]] * [[Norclostebol]] * [[Norethandrolone]] * [[Oxabolone]] * [[Oxandrolone]] * [[Oxymesterone]] * [[Oxymetholone]] * [[Prostanozol]] * [[Quinbolone]] * [[Stanozolol]] * [[Stenbolone]] * [[1-Testosterone]] * [[Tetrahydrogestrinone]] * [[Trenbolone]] {{col-end}} Drugs with similar structures and biological activity are also banned because new [[designer drug]]s of this sort are always being developed in order to beat the [[drug test]]s.
=== Endogenous anabolic androgenic steroids === The following substances, ordinarily produced naturally in the body, are prohibited when administered from outside the body. * [[Androstenediol]] * [[Androstenedione]] * [[Dihydrotestosterone]] * [[Prasterone]] (dehydroepiandrosterone DHEA) * [[Testosterone]]
==== Metabolites and isomers ==== Metabolites and isomers of endogenous anabolic androgenic steroids, including: {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[5α-Androstane-3α,17α-diol]] * [[5α-Androstane-3α,17β-diol]] * [[5α-Androstane-3β,17α-diol]] * [[5α-Androstane-3β,17β-diol]] * [[Androst-4-ene-3α,17α-diol]] * [[Androst-4-ene-3α,17β-diol]] * [[Androst-4-ene-3β,17α-diol]] * [[Androst-4-ene-3β,17α-diol]] * [[Androst-5-ene-3α,17α-diol]] * [[Androst-5-ene-3α,17β-diol]] * [[Androst-5-ene-3β,17α-diol]] {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[4-Androstenediol]] * [[5-Androstenedione]] * [[Epi-dihydrotestosterone]] * [[Epitestosterone]] * [[3α-Hydroxy-5α-androstan-17-one]] * [[3β-Hydroxy-5α-androstan-17-one]] * [[7α-Hydroxy-DHEA]] * [[7β-Hydroxy-DHEA]] * [[7-Keto-DHEA]] * [[19-Norandrosterone]] * [[19-Noretiocholanolone]] {{col-end}}
== Other anabolic agents == * [[Clenbuterol]] * [[Selective androgen receptor modulator]]s (SARMs) * [[Tibolone]] * [[Zeranol]] * [[Zilpaterol]]
== Hormones and related substances == Certain [[peptide]] [[hormone]]s increase bulk, strength, and oxygen-carrying red blood cells.
===Erythropoiesis-stimulating agent=== [[Erythropoiesis-stimulating agent]]s such as [[erythropoietin]] (EPO), [[darbepoetin]] (dEPO), [[hypoxia-inducible factor]] (HIF) stabilizers, [[methoxy polyethylene glycol-epoetin beta]] (CERA) and [[peginesatide]] (Hematide); [[growth hormone]] (hGH), [[insulin-like growth factor]]s ([[IGF-1]], etc.), [[fibroblast growth factor]]s (FGFs), [[hepatocyte growth factor]]s (HGF), [[mechano growth factor]]s (MGFs), [[platelet-derived growth factor]] (PDGF), [[vascular endothelial growth factor]] (VEGF), chorionic gonadotropin (banned in men only), [[somatotrophin]] (growth hormone), [[insulin]]s and [[corticotrophin]]s, [[corticosteroid]] mimics, and their releasing factor, are banned.
Also banned are any other growth factor affecting muscle, tendon or ligament protein synthesis/degradation, vascularization, energy utilization, regenerative capacity or fiber type switching; and other substances with similar chemical structure or similar biological effects.
=== Beta-2 agonists === All [[Beta2-adrenergic agonist|beta-2 agonists]] and their <small>D</small>- and <small>L</small>-[[Isomer|isomers]], are banned. However, [[formoterol]], [[salbutamol]], [[salmeterol]], and [[terbutaline]] may be used with a "therapeutic use exemption", only in the inhaled form.
=== Hormone antagonists and modulators === Hormone levels of a particular hormone, like testosterone, can be changed not only by administering it, but also by altering related hormones. For example, the estrogens [[estrone]] and [[estradiol]] are biosynthetically produced by the enzyme [[aromatase]], respectively, from [[androstenedione]] and testosterone, which are both produced from [[17α-hydroxyprogesterone]]. Thus, when the body senses low levels of estrogen, the precursor compounds 17α-hydroxyprogesterone, androstenedione, and testosterone are up-regulated. Likewise, interfering with a hormone's receptor leads to similar effects. Because of these natural hormone-hormone interdependent biosynthetic pathways and hormone-receptor interactions, all [[aromatase inhibitor]]s, including [[anastrozole]], [[letrozole]], [[aminoglutethimide]], [[exemestane]], [[formestane]], and [[testolactone]] are banned. [[Selective estrogen receptor modulator]]s, including [[raloxifene]], [[tamoxifen]] and [[toremifene]] are banned. [[Clomiphene]], [[cyclofenil]], [[fulvestrant]], and all other anti-estrogenic substances are banned. [[Myostatin]] inhibitors are banned. Metabolic modulators including [[peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor delta]] (PPARδ) [[agonist]]s (e.g., [[GW 501516|GW 1516]]), PPARδ-[[AMP-activated protein kinase]] (AMPK) axis agonists (e.g. [[AICA ribonucleotide|AICAR]]) are also banned. [[Meldonium]] was banned on 1 January 2016, which led to a [[Meldonium#Society and culture|Russian doping scandal]].
== Stimulants == Stimulants directly affect the central nervous system, increasing blood flow and heart rate. These drugs primarily help athletes in complex team sports like [[basketball]] and [[association football]] as well as choreographed sports like [[figure skating]] and [[artistic gymnastics]]. Stimulants that are banned include [[amphetamine]]s, [[beta-2 agonist]]s, [[ephedrine]], [[pseudoephedrine]], [[fencamfamine]], [[cocaine]], [[methamphetamine]]s, [[mesocarb]], and other substances with similar chemical structures and biological effects, including the following:
{{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=33%}} * [[Adrafinil]] * [[Adrenaline]] (local use allowed) * [[Amfepramone]] * [[Amiphenazole]] * [[Amphetamine]] * [[Amphetaminil]] * [[Armodafinil]] (active enantiomer of Modafinil) * [[Benfluorex]] * [[Benzphetamine]] * [[Benzylpiperazine]] * [[Bromantane]] (Ladasten) * [[Cathine]] (5 ug/ml urine limit) * [[Clobenzorex]] * [[Cocaine]] * [[Cropropamide]] * [[Crotetamide]] * [[Cyclazodone]] * [[Dimethylamphetamine]] * [[Ephedrine]] * [[Etamivan]] * [[Etilamphetamine]] {{col-break|width=33%}} * [[Etilefrine]] * [[Famprofazone]] * [[Fenbutrazate]] * [[Fencamfamin]] * [[Fencamine]] * [[Fenetylline]] * [[Fenfluramine]] * [[Fenproporex]] * [[Furfenorex]] * [[Heptaminol]] * [[Isometheptene]] * [[Levmethamfetamine]] * [[Meclofenoxate]] * [[Mefenorex]] * [[Mephentermine]] * [[Mesocarb]] * [[Methamphetamine (D-)]] * [[4-Methylamphetamine]] * [[Methylenedioxyamphetamine]] * [[Methylenedioxymethamphetamine]] * [[N-Methylephedrine|Methylephedrine]] {{col-break|width=33%}} * [[Methylphenidate]] * [[Modafinil]] * [[Nikethamide]] * [[Norfenefrine]] * [[Norfenfluramine]] * [[octopamine (drug)|Octopamine]] * [[Ortetamine]] * [[Oxilofrine]] * [[Parahydroxyamphetamine]] * [[Pemoline]] * [[Pentetrazol]] * [[Phendimetrazine]] * [[Phenmetrazine]] * [[Phentermine]] * [[4-Phenylpiracetam]] (carphedon) * [[Prenylamine]] * [[Prolintane]] * [[Propylhexedrine]] * [[Selegiline]] * [[Sibutramine]] * [[Strychnine]] * [[Tuaminoheptane]] {{col-end}}
== Diuretics and masking agents == [[Diuretic]]s, which increase the production of [[urine]], and masking agents, chemical compounds which interfere with drug tests, are banned for two reasons. First, by decreasing [[Water retention (medicine)|water retention]] and thus decreasing an athlete's weight, an important consideration in many speed sports (e.g. [[track and field]], [[speed skating]]), they increase the speed of an athlete. Secondly, increased urine production depletes the concentration of both the banned drugs and their metabolites, making their detection more difficult. Masking agents, on the other hand, work by making drug tests ineffective, leading to [[false-negative]] results. [[Desmopressin]], [[blood plasma|plasma]] expanders (such as [[glycerol]]; intravenous administration of [[albumin]], [[dextran]], [[hydroxyethyl starch]] and [[mannitol]]), [[probenecid]], and other substances with similar biological effects are also banned. Local application of [[felypressin]] in dental anesthesia is not prohibited.
===Diuretics=== The following diuretics, and chemicals with similar structure or biological activity are banned: {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Acetazolamide]] * [[Amiloride]] * [[Bendroflumethiazide]] * [[Bumetanide]] * [[Canrenone]] * [[Chlorthalidone]] * [[Chlorothiazide]] {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Etacrynic acid]] * [[Furosemide]] * [[Hydrochlorothiazide]] * [[Indapamide]] * [[Metolazone]] * [[Spironolactone]] * [[Triamterene]] {{col-end}}
== Narcotics and cannabinoids == [[Narcotic]] analgesics decrease the painful sensations of serious injuries, potentially allowing athletes to continue training for competition after an injury. While some [[painkiller]]s are allowed, including [[codeine]], the following are banned: {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Buprenorphine]] * [[Dextromoramide]] * [[Diamorphine]] (heroin) * [[Fentanyl]] and its derivatives * [[Methadone]] {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Morphine]] * [[Oxycodone]] * [[Oxymorphone]] * [[Pentazocine]] * [[Pethidine]] {{col-end}} The cannabis products [[marijuana]] and [[hashish]] are also banned in competition due to their cannabinoid content.
== Glucocorticoids == [[Glucocorticoid]]s are a class of [[corticosteroid]]s that affect the [[metabolism]] of [[carbohydrate]]s, [[fat]], and [[protein]]s, and regulate [[glycogen]] and [[blood pressure]] levels.They possess pronounced [[anti-inflammatory]] activity and cause alteration of [[connective tissue]] in response to injuries. The anti-inflammatory and connective tissue effects of glucocorticoids might mask injuries, leading to more serious injuries to athletes. Because of this and metabolic regulation effects, the administration of any glucorticoid orally, rectally, intraveniously, or intramuscularly is prohibited and requires a therapeutic use exemption. Topical uses of glucocorticoids does not require an exemption.
== Beta blockers == [[Beta blocker]]s are prohibited during competition in a number of sports; out of competition, they are prohibited only in [[Target archery|archery]] and [[Shooting sports|shooting]]. The prohibited beta blockers include: {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=33%}} *[[Acebutolol]] *[[Alprenolol]] *[[Atenolol]] *[[Betaxolol]] *[[Bisoprolol]] *[[Bunolol]] *[[Carteolol]] {{col-break|width=33%}} *[[Carvedilol]] *[[Celiprolol]] *[[Esmolol]] *[[Labetalol]] *[[Levobunolol]] *[[Metipranolol]] *[[Metoprolol]] {{col-break|width=33%}} *[[Nadolol]] *[[Oxprenolol]] *[[Pindolol]] *[[Propranolol]] *[[Sotalol]] *[[Timolol]] {{col-end}}
==Therapeutic Use Exemptions== Therapeutic Use Exemptions (TUEs) is a term used by WADA and the [[United States Anti-Doping Agency]] to denote banned substances that athletes may be "required to take to treat an illness or condition".<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.wada-ama.org/en/what-we-do/science-medical/therapeutic-use-exemptions|title=Therapeutic Use Exemptions|publisher=WADA| accessdate =13 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.usada.org/substances/tue/ |title=Therapeutic Use Exemptions (TUEs)|publisher=USADA| accessdate =13 September 2016}}</ref> These exemptions are regulated by the International Standard for Therapeutic Use Exemptions (ISTUE). The detection of such substances in samples is labelled by WADA as an "Adverse Analytical Finding" (AAF), which is distinct from "Anti-Doping Rules Violations" (ADRV).<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.wada-ama.org/en/questions-answers/ado-testing-statistics|title=ADO Testing Statistics|publisher=WADA| accessdate =13 September 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Doping at the Asian Games]] *[[Doping at the Commonwealth Games]] *[[Doping at the Olympics]]
==Footnotes== <references />
== References == * {{Citizendium|title=Drugs banned from the Olympics}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Drugs Banned By WADA}} [[Category:Drug-related lists|Banned By WADA]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games-related lists|Drugs Banned By WADA]] [[Category:Olympics-related lists|Drugs Banned By WADA]] [[Category:World Anti-Doping Agency prohibited substances| ]]

{{distinguish|Lobby (disambiguation){{!}}Lobby}} The '''Lobi''' belong to an [[ethnic group]] that originated in what is today [[Ghana]]. Starting around 1770, many Lobi peoples migrated into southern [[Burkina Faso]] and later into [[Côte d'Ivoire]]. The group consists of around 180,000 people.<ref>Klaus Schneider, "Ceramics and Brass of the Lobi people in Burkina Faso," in ''Earth and ore: 2500 years of African art in terra-cotta and metal,'' ed. Karl-Ferdinand Schaedler (Eurasburg: Edition Minerva, 1997), 111.</ref> [[Lobiri]] is the name of the language spoken by the Lobi people.
== Background == Lobi is a blanket term<ref>Dr. Carola Lentz identifies "Lobi" as a colonial ethnonym that the British adopted from Dyula intermediaries in the first decade of 20th century. See ''Ethnicity and the Making of History in Northern Ghana'' (2006: 80-81). Dyula use of the term was pejorative, signifying a naked, heathen, and pagan population. France created the "Cercle du Lobi" on December 29, 1898, for the sake of colonial/administrative convenience. See Jeanne-Marie Kambou Ferrand, "Guerre et résistance sous la période coloniale en pays lobi/birifor (Burkina Faso) au travers de photos d'époque," in ''Images d’Afrique et Sciences sociales Les pays lobi, birifor et dagara (Burkina Faso, Côte-d’Ivoire et Ghana) Actes du Colloque de Ouagadougou (10-15 décembre 1990)'', eds. Michele Fieloux, Jacques Lombard and Jeanne-Marie Kambou Ferrand (Paris: Karthala, 1990), 76.</ref> that refers to several closely related ethnic groups that comprise roughly 7% of the Burkinabe population, including the main Lobi proper, [[Birifor]], [[Dagara people|Dagara]], [[Dorossy]], [[Dyan]] (aka Jãa), Gan and [[Tenbo/Loron]] (aka Lorhon, Teese, Teguessie and Thuuna). It is important to recognize that among them, only the Gan belong to a politically centralized, and royal, society. Other groups are commonly referred to as "acephalous," which is misleading, but is meant to signal the absence of centralized political authority. Traditions vary among the groups, but some share a common sense of identity through participation in an initiation ceremony called ''joro'' (or ''dyoro''), which takes place every seven years. In terms of kinship, decsent is [http://sociologyindex.com/bilineal_descent.htm bilineal]. Many Lobi houses also share an architectural style, which consists of an earthen compound with walls made from horizontal courses. Most are single-story, and rarely include more than a few small, strategically placed holes to allow light in and to allow inhabitants to view the exterior surrounds. Historically, Lobi warriors used [[poisoned arrow]]s to fend off attackers (including French colonists). Largely through the use of village and personal shrines, they also share [[animist]] beliefs in order to maintain a productive relationship with the spiritual world. They achieve this specifically through regular interaction with spirits called ''thila,'' which inhabit a wide range of natural areas and man-made objects, such as ''bateba'', or anthropomorphic shrine figures that are now also well recognized in the art world. ''Thila'' are ambivalent beings that require regular offerings--via sacrifice-- in exchange for a wide range of protective and benevolent actions. They are intermediaries with Thangba Yu, the remote Creator God.
The name Lobi originates from two Lobiri words: ''lou'' (forest) and ''bi'' (children), meaning literally, "children of the forest" who settled initially on the left bank of the [[Mouhoun River]] or the [[Black Volta]] dividing Burkina Faso and [[Ghana]]. The Mouhoun River is important to Lobi peoples for many reasons. In terms of migration history, it marks an escape from slave raiders in present day Ghana. In myth, it symbolizes a dividing line between this world and the next, similar to the [[River Styx]] of [[Roman mythology]]. The Lobi crossed the Mounhoun centuries ago from east to west and settled in the lands and brought with them deep [[animism|animist]] beliefs and superstition. According to Lobi legend, the spirits of the deceased must return across the river to rejoin their honorable ancestors in the ancient world. The banks of the Mounhoun are used in initiation rites and fish and animals in the river are considered sacred.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Burkina Faso|last=Manson|first=Katrina|publisher=Bradt Travel Guides|year=2006|isbn=|location=|pages=241}}</ref>
== Lobi country == [[File:Beer brewing pot of Lobi people, Burkina Faso.jpg|thumb|A ceramic beer-brewing pot made and used by the Lobi people, [[Burkina Faso]].]] The Lobi inhabit parts of southern Burkina Faso. According to the director of the museum in [[Gaoua]] which is considered to be the capital of the Lobi, "The Lobi is a farmer, a hunter and a herder, but above all he is a warrior". Victims of slave raids, rival clans and civil disputes, they are among the fiercest and proudest inhabitants of Burkina Faso and were constantly under attack from the [[Guiriko]] and [[Kenedougou]] empires during the 19th century. Bakary Ouattara, brother of the founder of the Guiriko empire led an offensive against the Lobi in 1815, and despite setting fire to several villages he was eventually killed by a poisoned arrow. He was succeeded by Karakara who continued with the raids leading up to the devastating attack in 1850 where they suffered heavily and lost a great deal but were never completely defeated.
In June 1898, the French and the British made an agreement that the Lobi country would go under French jurisdiction. Attempts at controlling the peoples was difficult and the Lobi became known for their resistance using poisoned arrows in attempting to thwart the French colonial invasion. In 1914, during the outbreak of [[World War I]], the French colonial administration based in Gaoua began a merciless repression to the extent that the local were forbidden in copying any traits of the white man in the area. During the twentieth century some migrated into [[Côte d'Ivoire]].
== Animism == The Lobi are well documented for their [[animist]] beliefs, which involves regular interaction with ancestral and other types of spirits such as ''thila'' and ''kontuoursi''. Interaction with these spirits commonly takes place in a ''thilduu'' (domestic shrine room), ''dithil'' (village shrine), and at other places in nature inhabited by spirits. Christian missionaries working in southern Burkina Faso have reported that an elderly man in a Lobi village once renounced the spirits in favor of Christianity by discarding his fetishes in a nearby lake. As he turned his back on the traditions, the fetishes lept out of the lake onto his back again to reclaim him. Lobi people who convert to Christianity or Islam now usually burn their fetishes. Or, they may sell them on the market.
In Lobi animism, Thangba Yu is the creator of all living things. Lobi peoples have no direct contact with Him, but are dependent on nature spirits known as ''thila'', invisible intermediaries that can harness their supernatural powers towards good or evil. They set rules ''soser,'' which dictate how a Lobi should behave in important aspects of life. Similar to Greek or Roman gods, ''thila'' themselves are subject to mortal virtues and vices. In Lobi society, there is often a ''thildaar'' (village diviner) that may also act as a ''dithildaar'' (village priest; each village has only one) that interprets ''soser'' for the local community. A particularly intuitive and receptive ''thildaar'' is capable of interpreting as many as fifty or more spirits at a time.<ref>Manson & Knight, p. 221, Retrieved on June 17, 2008</ref>
== Architecture<ref>For an excellent analysis of one of the largest Lobi houses in history, see Klaus Schneider, ''La Grande Maison de Bindute Da: Histoire d'une habitation Lobi au Burkina Faso'' (Stuttgart: Franz Steiner Verlag, 1991).</ref> == Lobi dwellings are characterized as large rectangular or polygonal compounds known as ''maison soukala''<ref>''Soukala'' is a Dyula term. The Lobiri term for house is ''tyor'' or ''cuor.''</ref>. They are spaced well from each other and are composed of a single vast mud banco wall and a small entrance. An entrance to a Lobi house is a relatively recent development.<ref>'''citation needed'''</ref> At many houses, there is a ladder made from a large, Y-shaped tree trunk with notched steps, which lead up to the roof where inhabitants may access an interior granary and their own rooms below. Access to individual sleeping quarters is also available inside. Only the ''tyuordaarkuun'' (or head of the household; there is no "chief" in Lobi society) can give permission to enter the house. The roof is broad and flat and forms a terrace which provides a lookout point but can also be used for sleeping in the dry season. Domestic animals have their own space, and water is gathered from a well or the river. The rooms inside a Lobi house are very dark, and the size varies in relation to function. Each wife has a room for herself and her children where meals are prepared. Large earthenware jars used to hold water or other personal belongings are often stacked up against the kitchen walls and are a testament to the owner's economic status.
== References == * Manson, K., Knight, J. (2006), ''Burkina Faso'', p. 226, Bradt Travel Guides, The Globe Pequot Press Inc. <references/> * Labouret, Henri. ''Les Tribus du Rameau Lobi''. Institut d'Ethnologie, Paris, 1931. * Père, Madeleine. ''Les Lobi, Traditions et changement''. Vol.1 et 2, Siloë, Laval, 1988. * Meyer, Piet. ''Kunst und Religion der Lobi''. Museum Rietberg, Zurich, 1981. * Pirat, Claude-henri, "Lobi Statuary and the Statuary of Related Peoples, an Example of Cult Art", Tribal Arts Magazine, Paris/San Francisco, N°1, March 1994, p. 22-32. * Pirat, Claude-Henri, "Occult Conversations, or How the ''Thila'' Make the Law for the Lobi", in "Arts d'Afrique,Voir l'Invisible", Musée d'Aquitaine, Bordeaux, Hazan, Paris, 2011, p. 85-91. and p. 217-220. * de Rouville, Cécile. ''Organisation Sociale des Lobi, une Société Bilinéaire du Burkina Faso et de Côte d'Ivoire.'' L'Harmatan, Paris, 1987. * Bognolo, Daniela, "Lobi", 5 Continents Editions, Milan, 2007.
== External links == {{commons category|Lobi people}} *[https://africa.uima.uiowa.edu/peoples/show/Lobi Lobi information from University of Iowa]
{{Ethnic groups in Burkina Faso}} {{Ethnic groups in the Ivory Coast}} {{Authority control}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''MApEC''' (short for '''Multimedia Applications in Education Conference''') is an international [[scientific conference]] in [[Graz]], [[Austria]] on the topic of [[multimedia]] applications in [[education]].
The conference has been organized by the [[Fachhochschule|university of applied sciences]] [[FH Joanneum|FH JOANNEUM]] in September 2004 and September 2006.
In 2006, the Best Paper Award was awarded and the prizes were presented by Austria's First Lady [[Margit Fischer]].
== Keynote speakers 2006 == * Orit Hazzan, [[Technion - Israel Institute of Technology]], Israel * Ulrike Petersen, [[Fraunhofer Society|Fraunhofer]] Institute for Autonomous Intelligent Systems, Germany * [[Jimmy Wales]], [[Wikimedia Foundation]], USA
== Keynote speakers 2004 ==
* Mohammed Abdel-Hafez, [[United Arab Emirates University]], United Arab Emirates * David Cavallo, [[MIT Media Lab]], USA * Michael Haller, [[Fachhochschule Oberösterreich|FH Hagenberg]], Austria * Michael G. Wagner, [[Danube University Krems]], Austria
== External links == * [http://mapec.at/ MApEC Website]
[[Category:Conferences]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Alabama State Senators to [[:Category:Alabama state senators]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 17]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox State Senator |name=George Marc Keahey |image = |state_senate=Alabama |state=Alabama |district=22nd |term_start=2009 |term_end=2014 |preceded=Pat Lindsey |succeeded=Greg Albritton |party=[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |birth_date=1980 |birth_place= |death_date= |death_place= |alma_mater= [[University of Alabama]]
[[Cumberland School of Law]] |occupation=Attorney |spouse=Lara |residence=[[Grove Hill, Alabama]] |religion= |website=[http://keaheyforsenate.com/ Keahey for Senate] }} '''Marc Keahey''' was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] member of the [[Alabama Senate]], representing the 22nd district. ==Personal life and education== Keahey earned a business degree from the [[University of Alabama]], and in 2004 earned a JD from [[Cumberland School of Law]]. He has a wife, Lara, and three children.{{cite web|title=Senator Marc Keahey|url=http://www.legislature.state.al.us/senate/senators/senatebios/sd022.html|publisher=Alabama State Senate|accessdate=28 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003045802/http://www.legislature.state.al.us/senate/senators/senatebios/sd022.html|archivedate=3 October 2013|df=}} ==Career== After graduating from law school, Keahey served as a public defender, assistant district attorney, and private lawyer. Keahey was elected to the [[Alabama House of Representatives]] in 2006, and won a special election the [[Alabama Senate]] in 2009. He won election to a full Senate term in 2010. Keahey served on the Agriculture, Conservation and Forestry Committee, Business and Labor Committee, Fiscal Responsibility and Accountability Committee, Judiciary, and the Local Legislation No. 3 Committee. In 2010, Keahey was named Legislator of the Year by the Alabama Association of Conservation Districts.{{cite news|title=Senator named legislator of the year|url=http://www.fox10tv.com/onpolitix/alabama-onpolitix/senator-marc-keahey-named-legislator-of-the-year|accessdate=28 September 2013|newspaper=Fox 10 TV|date=16 November 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130928163103/http://www.fox10tv.com/onpolitix/alabama-onpolitix/senator-marc-keahey-named-legislator-of-the-year|archivedate=28 September 2013|df=}} He dropped his re-election bid in 2014 after the Republican-controlled Senate redrew his district to be majority Republican.http://blog.al.com/wire/2014/04/sen_marc_keahey_of_grove_hill.html ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://votesmart.org/candidate/biography/60438/marc-keahey#.UkcADIbryu8 Vote Smart page] *[https://twitter.com/MarcKeahey Twitter account] {{DEFAULTSORT:Keahey, Marc}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Grove Hill, Alabama]] [[Category:University of Alabama alumni]] [[Category:Cumberland School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Alabama lawyers]] [[Category:Members of the Alabama House of Representatives]] [[Category:Alabama state senators]] [[Category:Alabama Democrats]] [[Category:Public defenders]] [[Category:1980 births]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}} {{Use British English|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Baroness | name = Mary Stocks | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Mary Danvers Stocks | birth_date = 25 July 1891 | birth_place = | death_date = 6 July 1975 (aged 83) | death_place = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | other_names = | occupation = Writer | years_active = | known_for = Involvement with [[women's suffrage]], [[welfare state]], and social work | spouse = [[John Leofric Stocks]] (m. 1913, d. 1937) | parents = Roland Danvers Brinton
Constance Danvers Brinton (née Rendel) | relatives = [[Timothy Brinton|Tim Brinton]] (cousin)
[[Sal Brinton|Baroness Brinton]] (cousin) | notable_works = }} '''Mary Danvers Stocks, Baroness Stocks''' (née '''Brinton'''; 25 July 1891 – 6 July 1975) was a British [[writer]]. She was closely associated with the [[Strachey]], the [[Darwin–Wedgwood family|Wedgwood]] and the [[Ricardo (family)|Ricardo]] families. Her family was deeply involved in changes in the [[Victorian Era]] and Stocks herself was deeply involved in [[women's suffrage]], the [[welfare state]], and other aspects of social work.Majority of detail taken from a book called ''My Commonplace Book'' published by Peter Davies [[London]] 1971 reprint of the first 1970 edition with an {{ISBN|0-432-15750-6}} ==Early and private life== Stocks was born in London, the daughter a [[general practitioner]], Roland Danvers Brinton. Politicians [[Timothy Brinton|Tim Brinton]] and [[Sal Brinton|Sal Brinton, Baroness Brinton]] are cousins of Mary Stocks. Her mother Constance (née Rendel) was related to Eleanor and Philippa Strachey. She attended [[St Paul's Girls' School]]. She campaigned for [[women's suffrage]], and joined [[Millicent Fawcett]]'s moderate [[National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies]] (NUWSS) which later became the [[National Union of Societies for Equal Citizenship]] (NUSEC). She attended the [[London School of Economics]] (LSE), graduating in 1913 with a first-class degree in Economics.Duncan Sutherland, ‘Stocks , Mary Danvers, Baroness Stocks (1891–1975)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/31721 accessed 24 July 2015] She married the philosopher [[John Leofric Stocks]] in December 1913. He was a fellow of [[St John's College, Oxford]]. They had one son and two daughters. ==Career== During the First World War, Mary Stocks taught at the LSE and [[King's College, London]], while her husband served with in France with the [[King's Royal Rifle Corps]]; he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]]. She was a member of the NUWSS committee; she campaigned for [[family allowance]]s (finally granted in 1945) and for [[birth control]]; she was also an editor of the NUSEC journal ''Woman's Leader'', supported the ordination of [[women priests]], and [[equal pay]] for women. She also opposed restrictive women's clothing: as a matter of practicality, she did not wear a hat or make-up, preferred flat shoes, and kept her hair short. She became involved with the [[Workers' Educational Association]]. After the war, she moved to Oxford with her husband and taught economic history at [[Somerville College]] and [[Lady Margaret Hall]]. The family moved to [[Manchester]] in 1924, where her husband became a professor of philosophy. She was a magistrate in Manchester from 1930 to 1936. The family moved again to [[Liverpool]] in 1937 where her husband was briefly vice-chancellor for 6 months. After her husband died suddenly in 1937, Stocks moved back to London and became secretary of the [[London Council of Social Service]]. In 1939, she became Principal of [[Westfield College]] where she remained, including a period when the college was temporarily relocated to Oxford during the Second World War, until she retired in 1951. She served on a number of official government committees, often as the only woman. ==Politics== Stocks contested the [[London University (UK Parliament constituency)|London University]] seat at the [[United Kingdom general election, 1945|1945 general election]] as an Independent Progressive. Her opponent was the sitting MP who stood as an Independent supporter of the Churchill government. She came within 149 votes of winning. In 1946 Stocks contested a seat for the [[Combined English Universities (UK Parliament constituency)|Combined English Universities]] at a by-election as an [[Independent (politics)|Independent]] candidate. The by-election was caused by the death of [[Eleanor Rathbone]] (president of the NUSEC, whose biography Stocks wrote in 1949). She was the runner-up amongst five candidates. ==Later life== Stocks obtained wider public recognition in later life, when she became a [[radio personality|radio broadcaster]] and appeared frequently on ''[[Any Questions?]]'', on quiz shows and gave religious talks.BBC interview Frankly Speaking She eventually retired to the [[House of Lords]], having been created a [[life peer]] as '''Baroness Stocks''', of the [[Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea]] on 17 January 1966,{{London Gazette |issue=43877 |date=18 January 1966 |page=666}} where she initially took the Labour Party whip before becoming a [[cross-bencher]] in 1974. She wrote her autobiography. She was commissioned to write a book on the first 50th years of the WEA ([[Workers Educational Association]]) which had been founded in 1903, published in 1953.Detail from a copy of the book published by George Allen and Unwin in 1953 with no ISBN She received several honorary doctorates, including ones from [[Manchester University]] in 1955, [[Liverpool University]] in 1956, and [[Leeds University]] in 1957. She was a member of the advisory committee to the [[Anti-Concorde Project]]. She died in Kensington in July 1975, shortly before her 84th birthday. ==Bibliography== * ''Fifty Years in Every Street'' * ''[[Eleanor Rathbone]]'' * ''History of the [[Workers' Educational Association]]'' * ''A One Hundred years of [[District Nursing]]'' * ''[[Ernest Simon, 1st Baron Simon of Wythenshawe|Ernest Simon]] of [[Manchester]] (UK)'' * ''Unread Best-seller'' * ''My Commonplace Book'' ([[Autobiography]]) * '' The Workers Educational Association'': The First Fifty Years. ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} ==See also== * [[List of Life Peerages]] ==References== * ''British Parliamentary Election Results 1918-1949'', compiled and edited by F.W.S. Craig (Macmillan 1977) * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05rd9by Dr Mary Stocks] interviewed in 1964 for the BBC radio programme ''Frankly Speaking''. Accessed April 2015 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Stocks, Mary}} [[Category:1891 births]] [[Category:1975 deaths]] [[Category:British women historians]] [[Category:Economic historians]] [[Category:English suffragists]] [[Category:Female life peers|Stocks, Mary Danvers Stocks, Baroness Stocks]] [[Category:Feminism and history]] [[Category:English women writers]] [[Category:Writers from London]] [[Category:Women of the Victorian era]] [[Category:Fellows of Somerville College, Oxford]] [[Category:People associated with Westfield College]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2010}}
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Nezihe Muhiddin | image = Nezihe muhiddin.jpg | imagesize = 185px | caption = | office1 = | president1 = | term_start1 = | term_end1 = | predecessor1 = | successor1 = | office2 = | primeminister2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = |office4 = |term_start4 = |term_end4 = |constituency4 = | birth_date = 1889 | birth_place = | death_date = 10 February, 1958 | death_place = | nationality = Turkish | spouse = | religion = | party = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = }}
'''Nezihe Muhiddin''' ([[Turkish language|Modern Turkish]]: Nezihe Muhittin; 1889 – 10 February, 1958<ref>[http://www.turkkadinlarbirligi.org/index.php?p=genel_icerik&content=tarihce_tuzuk Tarihçe/Tüzük] in website of Türk Kadınlar Birliği. {{Tr icon}}</ref>) was a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] [[women's rights]] activist, [[suffragette]], journalist, writer and political leader.
== Career ==
She is the founder of the first party of the [[Republic of Turkey]], Kadınlar Halk Fırkası (People’s Party for Women or [[Women's People Party]]) in July 1923. KHF was founded for the political and social rights of women. Due to the political situation during the time, it was not recognized officially by the modern Turkish state.
Muhiddin then founded Türk Kadınlar Birliği (Turkish Women's Union). Türk Kadınlar Birliği continued to press for political equality. In 1927 the Union decided to promote a [[feminism|feminist]] male candidate to champion women's rights in the parliament, but he was unsuccessful.
She spent her life working to improve the quality of the lives of Turkish women.
==Publications==
===Books=== *''Şebab-ı Tebah'' (''The Lost Youth'') *''Benliğim benimdir'' (''My Ego is Mine'') *''Güzellik Kraliçesi'' (''The Beauty Queen'') *''Boz Kurt'' (''The Grey Wolf'') *''İstanbul'da Bir Landru'' (''A Landru in Istanbul'') *''Ateş Böcekleri'' (''Fire Flies'') *''Bir Aşk Böyle Bitti'' (''This is How A Love Ended'') *''Çıplak Model'' (''The Naked Model'') *''İzmir Çocuğu'' (''The Child of Izmir'') *''Avare Kadın'' (''Wastrel Woman'') *''Bir Yaz Gecesiydi'' (''It Was a Summer Night'') *''Çıngıraklı Yılan'' (''The Rattlesnake'') *''Kalbim Senindir'' (''My Heart Belongs To You'') *''Sabah Oluyor'' (''Turning Out to be Morning'') *''Gene Geleceksin'' (''You Will Come Back'') *''Sus Kalbim Sus!'' (''Shush, My Heart, Shush!'') *''Türk Kadını'' (''Turkish Woman'')
==References== {{reflist}}

* ''Nezihe Muhiddin: an Ottoman Turkish women's rights defender" by Yaprak Zihnioglu.
* ''Kadınsız İnkılap/ Nezihe Muhiddin, Kadınlar Halk Fırkası, Kadın Birliği.'' by Yaprak Zihnioğlu, Metis Yayınları 2003

Yeni Şafak Newspaper Article in Turkish.] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930181751/http://www.radikal.com.tr/haber.php?haberno=215298%2F Ottoman Women's Movement, Turkish article in Radikal Newspaper] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927220316/http://www.radikal.com.tr/ek_haber.php?ek=ktp&haberno=5573%2F Muhiddin, life and books. SesOnline Article by Ayse Hur in Turkish]

'''''No-pan kissa''''' (ノーパン喫茶, literally "no-[[panties]] cafe") is a Japanese term for [[maid café]]s where the [[waitress]]es wear short skirts with no [[underwear]]. The floors, or sections of the floor, were sometimes mirrored.<ref name="Uninvited">{{cite web |title=No-pan kissa (No-panty cafes) |url=http://www.japanfortheuninvited.com/articles/no-pan-kissa.html |website=Japan for the Uninvited |accessdate=5 August 2018 |date=23 June 2006}}</ref>
Customers order drinks and [[snacks]] and generally touch, the staff.<ref name=allison1994>{{cite book|title=Nightwork: sexuality, pleasure, and corporate masculinity in a Tokyo hostess club|first=Anne|last=Allison|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=1994|isbn=0-226-01487-8 |pages=131–132}}</ref> The shops otherwise look like normal coffee shops, rather than sex establishments, although they charged a premium price for the coffee.<ref name="Uninvited" /> Previously, most sex establishments had been establishments, such as [[soapland]]s and [[pink salon]]s, with professional prostitutes. ''No-pan kissa'' were a popular employment choice amongst some women because they paid well and generally required little sexual contact with the customers.
The first one to open was in [[Osaka]] in 1980.<ref>{{cite book|title=Behind the mask: on sexual demons, sacred mothers, transvestites, gangsters, drifters and other Japanese cultural heroes|first=Ian|last=Buruma|authorlink=Ian Buruma|publisher=Pantheon Books|year=1984|isbn=0-394-53775-0 |page=111}}</ref> Initially, all of them were in remote areas outside the traditional [[entertainment district]]s. Within a year, large numbers had opened in many more places, such as major [[railway station]]s.<ref>{{cite book|title=Neighborhood Tokyo|series=Studies of the East Asian Institute|first=Theodore C.|last=Bestor|publisher=Stanford University Press|year=1989|isbn=0-8047-1797-4 |page=42}}</ref>
In the 1980s (the peak of the boom in these shops), many started to have [[Toplessness|topless]] or bottomless waitresses.<ref name="Anahori">{{cite web |last1=Anahori |first1=Tadashi |title=Revisit the retro glory of Japan’s 1980s no-pan kissa (no-panties cafes) {{!}} Tokyo Kinky Sex, Erotic and Adult Japan |url=http://www.tokyokinky.com/revisit-retro-glory-1980s-no-pan-kissa-no-panties-cafe-japan/ |website=www.tokyokinky.com |accessdate=5 August 2018 |date=1 February 2017}}</ref> However, at this point, the number of such shops started to decline rapidly.<ref name="Uninvited" />
Eventually, such coffee shops gave way to [[fashion health]] (massage) clubs and few no-pan kissa, if any, remain.<ref name="Uninvited" /> The [[New Amusement Business Control and Improvement Act]] came into force on February 13, 1985, which further restricted the [[sex industry]] and protected the more traditional businesses.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Suei |first1=Akira |title=Araki - Tokyo Lucky Hole |url=https://www.michaelhoppengallery.com/store/publications/13/ |website=Michael Hoppen Gallery |accessdate=23 September 2018 |language=en |date=1990}}</ref>
In addition to ''no-pan kissa'', there have also been ''no-pan'' [[shabu-shabu]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m-YVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-RQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5251,3800843&dq=no-pan+shabu+shabu&hl=en |journal=New Sunday Times|title=Ministry officials 'demanded' sex club entertainment|date=28 January 1998|accessdate=2012-12-28}}</ref> and ''no-pan'' [[karaoke]].<ref name=allison1994/><ref name=allison2000>{{cite book|title=Permitted and prohibited desires: mothers, comics, and censorship in Japan|first=Anne|last=Allison|publisher=University of California Press|year=2000|isbn=0-520-21990-2 |page=170}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} * Akira Suei, "The Lucky Hole as the Black Hole" in [[Nobuyoshi Araki]], ''Tokyo Lucky Hole'', {{ISBN|3-8228-4681-3}}.
{{Types of coffeehouses}} {{Prostitution in Japan}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:No-Pan Kissa}}

{{multiple issues|{{unreferenced|date=October 2014}} {{no footnotes|date=February 2013}}{{External links|date=April 2018}}{{confusing|date=April 2018}} {{lead too long|date=April 2018}} }} '''Open publishing''' is a process of creating news or other content that is transparent to the readers. They can contribute a story and see it instantly appear in the pool of stories publicly available. Those stories are filtered as little as possible to help the readers find the stories they want. Readers can see editorial decisions being made by others. They can see how to get involved and help make editorial decisions. If they can think of a better way for the software to help shape editorial decisions, they can copy the software because it is [[Free and open-source software|free and open source]] to change it and start their own site. If they want to redistribute the news, they can, preferably on an open publishing site.
Internet sites run on open publishing software allow anyone with Internet access to [[user-generated content|visit the site and upload content directly]] without having to penetrate the filters of traditional media. Several fundamental principles tend to inform the organizations and sites dedicated to open publishing, though they do so to varying degrees. These principles include non-hierarchy, public participation, minimal editorial control, and transparency.
Open publishing idea embedded the same concept, although didn't mention [[Eric S. Raymond]]'s major insight. In open publishing problematic content is shallow. Given a large enough audience, peers, readers and commentators, almost all problematic content will quickly be noticed, highlighted and fixed. Arnison's Law: "Given enough eyeballs, problematic content is shallow".
It should be distinguished from [[open access publishing]] – the publishing of material organized in such a way that there is no financial or other barrier to the user. (All or almost all open publishing is in fact also [[open access]].)
== Examples == * [[Independent Media Center]] * [[Kuro5hin]] * [[Slashdot]] * [[Wikipedia]] * [[Wikinews]]
== See also == * [[Collaborative writing]] * [[Fair Access to Science and Technology Research Act]], U.S. House of Representatives * [[Free content]] * [[Open access]] * [[Open content]] * [[Open source journalism]] * [[Participatory economics]] * [[Participatory journalism]] * [[Peer review]] ==References== <references/> ==External links== * [http://www.purplebark.net/maffew/cat/openpub.html Open publishing is the same as free software.] - the document which popularized the term within the [[Independent Media Center|Indymedia]], the first widespread use of the term. * [http://www.cybered.org/open_jur.html Hebrew article on Open Publishing] regarding [http://www.indymedia.org.il Indymedia Israel]. * [http://depts.washington.edu/ccce/digitalMedia/publishing.html Center for Communication & Civic Engagenment on Open Publishing] * [http://slashdot.org/features/00/06/19/1714239.shtml Analysis: The Rise Of Open Media] * [http://dru.ca/imc/open_pub.html Three Proposals for Open Publishing] * [http://opl.rit.edu The Open Publishing Lab at the Rochester Institute of Technology] - A research lab that develops open source applications for open publishing. *[https://www.ijert.org/about-journal/open-access-statement Open Access Statement]
[[Category:Publishing]] [[Category:Citizen media]] [[Category:Collective intelligence]] [[Category:New media]]

The '''Penja''' are a [[Muslim]] community found in the state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]] in [[India]] and the [[Punjab (Pakistan)|Punjab]] province of [[Pakistan]]. They are also known as '''Naddaf''', and in Pakistan their preferred designation is '''Shaikh Mansoori'''.<ref name="Bansal">People of India Punjab Volume XXXVII edited by I.J.S. Bansal and Swaran Singh pages 353 to 357 Manohar</ref>
== Origin ==
The Penja like many communities in India have acquired their name from their traditional occupation. In the case of the Penja, they were and many still are cotton carders and produce a coarse thread. They are said to be by origin members of the [[Muslim Teli|Teli]] caste who formed an [[endogamy|endogamous]] sub-group when they changed their occupation from oil pressing to cotton carding. Historically, the Penja community was concentrated in what is now Indian or [[East Punjab]], which led to the migration of the majority of the community to [[Pakistan]] at the time of the [[partition of India]] in 1947. A rump community is still found in the districts [[Ropar]], [[Patiala]] and Sangrur. In Pakistan, the community is found mainly in [[Faisalabad]], [[Sahiwal]], [[Khanewal]] and [[Toba Tek Singh]] districts, and prefers to be known as Shaikh Mansoori or sometimes just Shaikh. The Penja speak [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]], but most who are now settled in [[Pakistan]] also speak [[Urdu]]. They are entirely [[Sunni]], and are now fairly orthodox.<ref name="Bansal"></ref>
== Present circumstances ==
The Penja historically practiced the custom of clan exogamy. This practice has now been discontinued. Their larger clans referred to as ''biradarus'' include the Raunji, Dedan, Phapute, Jand, Harim, Sohatte, Ahre, [[Kamboh]], Bedham, Male Hans, Behlim, Alimi, [[Bhatti]], [[Chauhan]], [[Panwar]] and [[Gill]]. The Penja are strictly [[endogamy|endogamous]], but there are occasional marriages with the [[Muslim Teli|Teli]] community.<ref name="Bansal"></ref>
Like most artisan castes, the Penja have seen a decline in their traditional occupation of cotton carding. With the spread of mechanized textile mills, the demand for their traditional coarse thread has disappeared. Many are now employed as agricultural labourers, with animal husbandry being an important subsidiary occupation. In India, the community has been granted [[Other Backward Class]] (OBC) status, which allows the community to avail benefits of the [[Government of India]]'s affirmative action schemes.<ref name="Bansal"></ref>
== See also == * [[Behna]] * [[Pinjara]]
== References ==

revision.text:
{{short description|Indian ethnic group}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = Punjabi Diaspora
{{Nastaliq|پنجابی}} / ਪੰਜਾਬੀ |population = 10 million{{rs|date=November 2018}} |langs = • [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]] • [[English language|English]] |rels= • [[Image:Allah-green.svg|18px]] [[Islam]] • [[Image:Om.svg|15px]] [[Hinduism]] • [[Image:Khanda.svg|15px]] [[Sikhism]] • [[Image:Christian cross.svg|10px]] [[Christianity]] • [[File : Jain Prateek Chihna.svg|26px]] [[Jainism]] • [[File: Dharma wheel.svg|25px]] [[Buddhism]] • [[non-religious]] |related=• [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indian Diaspora]], [[Sikh diaspora]], [[Pakistani diaspora]], [[South Asian Diaspora]] }} The '''Punjabi diaspora''' refers to the descendants of ethnic [[Punjabis]] who emigrated out of the [[Punjab region]] of the [[Indian subcontinent]] to the rest of the world. Punjabis are one of the largest ethnic groups in both the [[Pakistani diaspora|Pakistani]] and [[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin|Indian diasporas]]. The Punjabi diaspora numbers around 10 million, mainly concentrated in Britain, North America, Southeast Asia and the Middle East.http://apnaorg.com/articles/ishtiaq8/ - Punjabis Without Punjabi{{rs|date=November 2018}} ==Afghanistan== {{Main|Punjabis in Afghanistan}} ==Australia== {{Further|Indian Australian|Pakistani Australian}} Punjabis migrated to [[Australia]] from other parts of the Punjabi diaspora, as well from the state of Punjab itself. The Majority were Sikh & Hindu Punjabis instead of Muslims being the majority.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R9PXaUmk-sAC&pg=PA74&d |title=Between Colonialism and Diaspora: Sikh Cultural Formations in an Imperial World |author=Tony Ballantyne}} ==Canada== {{Further|Indian Canadian|Pakistani Canadian}} 85% of [[Indo-Canadians]] in [[British Columbia]] are Punjabi Sikhs,{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6lXZfWr68FAC&pg=PA317&d |title=Foreign policy annual |author=Mahendra Gaur |page=317}} including former [[premier of British Columbia]], [[Ujjal Dosanjh]]. ==Persian Gulf states== {{See also|Pakistanis in the Middle East}} In the Gulf states, the largest group among Pakistani expatriates are the Punjabis.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GNJHlFTPBT0C&pg=PA194&d |title=Democracy and Authoritarianism in South Asia: A Comparative and Historical Perspective |author=Ayesha Jalal |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1995}} ==Hong Kong== Among Hong Kong Indian adolescents, Punjabi is the third most common language other than [[ hindi and Cantonese language|Cantonese]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vvCWT8XHK8QC&pg=PA231&d |title=Language in Hong Kong at Century's End |author=Martha Carswell Pennington |publisher=Hong Kong University Press |year=1998 |page=219}} The Punjabis were influential in the military, and in line with the British military thinking of the time (namely, the late 19th century and early 20th century) Punjabi Sikhs, Punjabi Hindus and Punjabi Muslims formed two separate regiments. The regiments were as follows: *Punjab regiment: 25,000 soldiers (50% Muslim, 40% Hindu and 10% Sikh) *Sikh Regiment: 10,000 soldiers (80% Sikh, 20% Hindu) In 1939, Hong Kong's police force included 272 [[European ethnic groups|Europeans]], 774 [[Indian ethnic groups|Indians]] (mainly Punjabis) and 1140 [[Han Chinese|Chinese]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=di-dugl7o4kC&pg=PA70&d |title=The Cambridge Survey of World Migration |author=Robin Cohen |publisher=Cambridge University Press |year=1995 |page=70}} Punjabis dominated Hong Kong's police force until the 1950s.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7QEjPVyd9YMC&pg=PA275&d |title=Encyclopedia of Diasporas: Immigrant and Refugee Cultures Around the World. Volume I: Overviews and Topics; Volume II: Diaspora Communities |author1=Carol R. Ember |author2=Melvin Ember |author3=Ian A. Skoggard |publisher=Springer |year=2004}} From the 2006 Government by-census results, it shows a population of roughly 20,444 Indians and roughly 11,111 Pakistanis residing at the former British territory.{{cite book |url=http://www.bycensus2006.gov.hk/en/data/data3/statistical_tables/index.htm#A1|title=Census and Statistics Department 2006 Population By-census: Section A, Table A105|author=Hong Kong SAR Government|publisher=Hong Kong SAR Government |year=2007}} ==Japan== There are 70,000 Punjabis.{{cite web|url=https://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/14483/JA|title=Punjabi in Japan|first=Joshua|last=Project|publisher=}} ==Kenya== Most Kenyan Asians are Gujaratis, but the second largest group are Punjabis.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GHlkAAAAMAAJ&d |title=Language in Kenya |author=Wilfred Whiteley}} ==Malaysia== Although most [[Malaysian Indians]] are [[Tamil Malaysian|Tamils]], there were also many Punjabis that immigrated to [[Malaysia]]. According to Amarjit Kaur as of 1993 there were 60, 000 Punjabis in Malaysia.{{cite book |title=Historical Dictionary of Malaysia |publisher=Scarecrow Press |author=Amarjit Kaur |year=1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G226AAAAIAAJ&d}} Robin Cohen estimates the number of Malaysian Sikhs as 30, 000 (as of 1995). Recent figures state that there are 130,000 Sikhs in Malaysia.{{cite web|url=http://apnaorg.com/articles/ishtiaq8/|title=Punjabis Without Punjabi|website=apnaorg.com}} ==New Zealand== In New Zealand, Punjabis are one of the largest group of [[Indian New Zealander]]s.{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/NewZealanders/NewZealandPeoples/Indians/1/en |title=Indians - Indian communities - Te Ara Encyclopedia of New Zealand}} ==Singapore== The third largest group among [[Indo-Singaporean]]s in 1980 were Punjabis (after [[Tamils]] - who form a majority of Indo-Singaporeans - and [[Malayalis]]), at 7.8% of the Indo-Singaporean population.{{cite book |title=Language Change Via Language Planning: Some Theoretical and Empirical Aspects with a Focus on Singapore |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zRXR1EVYIHkC&pg=PA77&vq=Punjabis&dq=Punjabis+in+Singapore&source=gbs_search_s&cad=0#PPA77,M1 |page=77}} There is Punjabi Society Singapore for Punjabi's to celebrate their festivals, meet other Punjabi's in various occasion through www.punjabisocietysingapore.com ==Thailand== Most [[Indians in Thailand]] are Punjabis.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TeExjdWUmJYC&pg=PA915&d |title=Indian Communities in Southeast Asia |author1=Kernial Singh Sandhu |author2=A. Mani }} ==United Kingdom== {{Main|British Punjabis}} [[File:Southall station sign.jpg|right|thumb|British sign from [[Southall]] in [[English language|English]] and [[Punjabi language|Punjabi]]]] In the United Kingdom, around two-thirds of direct migrants (excluding South Asians that immigrated from the Caribbean, Fiji and other regions) from South Asia were Punjabi. The remaining third is mostly [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]] and [[Bengali people|Bengali]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=74ZVFb37zuIC&pg=PA20&d |title=Desh Pardesh |authors=Roger Ballard, Marcus Banks |publisher=C. Hurst & Co. Publishers |year=1994 |pages=19–20}} They form a majority of both the South Asian British Sikh and Hindu communities. Most "twice-migrants" were also [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] or [[Gujarati people|Gujarati]].{{cite book |title=South Asian Folklore: An Encyclopedia : Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India, Nepal, Pakistan, Sri Lanka |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ienxrTPHzzwC&pg=PA158&d |author1=Peter J. Claus |author2=Sarah Diamond |author3=Margaret Ann Mills |page=158}} ===Population of Sikhs by UK Censuses=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year || Population |- | 1951 || 10,000 |- | 1961 || 26,000 |- | 1971 || 120,000 |- | 1981 || 216,020 |- | 1991 || 269,000 |- | 2001 || 336,000 |- |}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GDMTeC_WB0oC&pg=PA23&dq=british+sikhs+1951|title=Muslim Britain: Communities Under Pressure|first=Tahir|last=Abbas|date=4 June 2005|publisher=Zed Books|via=Google Books}} ==United States== [[File:Panjabi USC2000 PHS.svg|thumb|Punjabis in the US by State]] {{main|Punjabi American}} The earliest South Asian immigrants to the United States were Punjabis, who mostly immigrated to the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]], particularly [[California]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f0RmIjewCxkC&pg=PA127&d |title=The New Ethnics: Asian Indians in the United States |authors= Parmatma Saran, Edwin Eames}} Half of [[Pakistani American]]s are Punjabis.http://www.everyculture.com/multi/Le-Pa/Pakistani-Americans.html - Under "Language" 85% of the early Indian immigrants to the US were Sikhs, although they were branded by [[White American]]s as "[[Hindu, California|Hindus]]".{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F-NNO9jGfIQC&pg=PA61&d |title=Other Immigrants: The Global Origins of the American People |author=David M. Reimers |publisher=NYU Press |year=2005 |page=61}} 90% of Indians who settled in the [[Central Valley (California)|Central Valley]] of [[California]] were Punjabi Sikhs.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zz0HRk65MwUC&pg=PA2&d |title=Accommodation Without Assimilation |author=Margaret A. Gibson}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Punjabi diaspora}} {{Overseas Asians}} {{overseas Pakistani}} {{NRI-PIO}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Punjabi Diaspora}} [[Category:Punjab]] [[Category:Pakistani diaspora]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in India]] [[Category:Social groups of Pakistan]] [[Category:Punjabi diaspora| ]]
